column3: The Third Wave was a social experiment conducted by history teacher, Ron Jones. The experiment put his students in a disciplinary environment. The first wave consisted of simple things such as proper seating. Over the course of a few days, Mr. Jones' students had been drilled so hard in class, that they were following these strict rules in and out of class. This eventually led to many students, whom were not in the class, to be initiated by other members. The experiment became so popular within the school walls, that there were now over two hundred participants as opposed to the original thirty. Mr. Jones saw how quickly people were changing, and how fast people were catching on, he thought it was getting out of hand, which led him to terminating the movement.
column4: The Third Wave social experiment demonstrated the transformative power of focused instruction. Through repeated drilling and reinforcement, students were compelled to follow strict classroom protocols. This led to an influx of students outside the regular classroom participating in the experiment, ultimately surpassing the initial enrollment of thirty participants. Recognizing the rapid shift and widespread participation, Mr. Jones felt that the experiment needed to be stopped as it intensified.

column3: onas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant‚Äîa machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor‚Äîa process known to the workers as ‚Äúgiving them thirty per cent.‚Äù Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as ‚ÄúNumber Three Grade,‚Äù but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade‚Äîthere was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes‚Äîthey had what they called ‚Äúboneless hams,‚Äù which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and ‚ÄúCalifornia hams,‚Äù which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy ‚Äúskinned hams,‚Äù which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them‚Äîthat is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled ‚Äúhead cheese!‚Äù

column3: As described by Aristotle, 3 ideal elements of an ideal tragedy include "imitation" of reality,  a "well- constructed plot", and "change of fortune" that is not expected by the audience. Aristotle uses the method of imitation in order to "excite pity and fear" with stories that reflect "of a men like ourselves", which hooks the audience more into the tragedy becuase it could be applied to real life scenarios.. He said that a tragedy must consist of a "well-constructed plot", that is "complex " and complete, in which it has a "single issue" through the beginning, middle and end. Lastly, Aristotle also described the third element of change of fortune, as he said, "The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad." He says that these 3 elements, along with others,  should create a "perfect tragedy".
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  Aristotle described three core elements of a tragic play according to the Greek philosopher. They were imitation of reality, a well-structured plot, and surprise or the unexpected change of fate. He used the method of imitation in his stories to evoke grief and fear in audience members by creating stories relatable to real life experiences. A tragedy must have a well-developed plot, be complex and complete with a single central theme that unfolds over its entire duration. Finally, the change of fortune should occur in reverse, from good to bad, rather than from bad to good. These elements combined, according to Aristotle, create a perfect tragedy.

column3: Aristotle believes there are certain elements that make a tragedy a tragedy. A few of teh elements he presumes must be in a tragedy, it the idea of a double thread plot. A double thread plot is something that has someone benefiting from the good and someone benefiting from the bad like the Odyssey. A second element would be the idea that a tragedy has something go from good to bad and not bad to good like normal works of literature do. The last thing woul dbe the idea that it imitates fear and pity. It doesn't do it itself, however it acts like it is trying to produce it.
column4: Aristotle believed that certain elements of tragedy were essential to the genre. The first element was the presence of a double thread plot, which depicted a situation where someone benefited from the tragedy and someone else benefited from the misery. The second element was a reversal of the traditional tragic pattern, where the protagonist began with happiness and ended with misery, rather than starting with misery and ending with happiness. Lastly, Aristotle believed that a tragedy should have an element of fear and pity that acted as a mirror to human suffering.

column3: The summarization of at least three of the elements possessed by an ideal tragedy as it is described by the Greek philosopher Aristotle is that the plot of the tragedy should be composed upon the complex plan instead of the simple one, which imitates and possesses actions and occurrences within which result within the feelings of both fear and pity within the individual witnessing or reading eh piece, which is the identifying staple of tragic pieces. While the primary character or the hero within these pieces should be an individual which is situated between the two extremes of incredibly just an incredibly evil, they should be neither be the epitome of saintly and good while they should neither have their downfall be brought to them due to their depravity or vice which they possess and should instead occur due to their own frailty or a minute error of judgment or mistake, and they should be an individual which is both prosperous and renowned being well known and plentiful within their lives or be other individuals connected to families which are of this variety. As well as that the plot which is maintained by these works should possess a singular issue or complication which it is revolving around, and the alteration within the character's fortune should be from that of good to poor and it should not occur due to a vice they possess and instead due to an error within the character previously described or one which is even better than that, though never worse, and within these pieces, there is what people call a bad or unhappy ending.
column4: Sure, here's the rewritten passage:  A tragedy, according to Aristotle's philosophical analysis, should be characterized by a complex plot that goes beyond simple themes and actions and occurrences. The lead character, inhabiting a position between extremes of both virtue and evil, should undergo a development that emerges from personal flaws and mistakes rather than arising solely from inherent flaws or vice. The plot should revolve around a singular, pivotal issue or complication, with the character's fortunes changing from good to poor through an error or a superior act rather than through a vice. The ending should, in the eyes of Aristotle, be a form of misfortune, not stemming from inherent flaws but from a miscalculation on the part of the character.

column3: The meatpacking factories had many means of covering up and using spoiled meat. One such way was by pumping the ham with a "much stronger pickle that destroyed the odor." Another way they were able to use spoiled meat was by pulling out the bone, which is where "the bad part generally lay." In this way the rest of the meat was still used. When an entire ham was spoiled, moldy,  and white, is was used for sausage where "no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." Using these methods, the meatpackers were able to use and distribute meat of terrible quality for consumption.
column4: The meatpacking factories employed several deceptive practices to mask the unacceptable quality of their products. One technique involved injecting spoiled meat with a "subtle" pickle, which chemically destroyed the unpleasant odor. Another method involved removing the bone from the meat, thereby positioning the bad parts in a favorable location for reusing. When a whole ham began to spoil, it was rendered suitable for sausage production, despite its undesirable appearance and odorless nature.

column3: There are many elements to an ideal tragedy according to ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle. To begin with, character is a big element in order to achieve an ideal tragedy. Aristotle talks about how a character should not be a bad man or virtuos man, but a man in between those two extremes. A man who is not eminently good and just, yet their downfall is caused byerror of judgement or frailty. Some examples are Oedupis or Thyestes. This is because they are relatable to the viewers and pity or excitement can not be aroused  from simple adversity to prosperity or prosperity to adversity. Another key element is the plot. It should be a single plot where change of fortune should be from good to bad. Some of the greatest tragedies like the fortunes of Oedipus or Alcmaeon can back this up. Lastly, the ending is also a major facet of the ideal tragedy. Although the ending may not satisfy the viewers, if done right, it can be the most tragic like Euripides.
column4: Aristotle emphasized the importance of character and plot in crafting an ideal tragedy. He presented that characters should be neither virtuous nor wicked, but exist somewhere in between. Examples of this were Oedupis and Thyestes, who were relatable and evoked both pity and excitement. The plot should focus on a single, overarching change in fortune from good to evil. Great tragic narratives such as those of Oedipus and Alcmaeon exemplify this principle. Finally, the ending serves as a crucial component of the ideal tragedy, and when done right, it can be the most powerful and tragic ending.

column3: The plot should be well constructed and not have two issues but one single one. column4: The screenplay should be meticulously crafted, possessing a balanced narrative devoid of two contrasting issues, but with a single underlying theme. The protagonist should exhibit complexities, lacking excessive heroism or depravity, rather mirroring the human experience with relatable character flaws. Additionally, the plot should unfold in a way that transforms misfortune into prosperity, not the other way around.

column3: One element of an ideal tragedy, as summarized by Aristotle, is that there should be a serious change in circumstances of the main character, specifically a change from good circumstances to bad, instead of bad to good. Aristotle says "The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad." Aristotle argues that if the fortune changed from bad to good, then it wouldn't invoke any feelings of pity in us, as it wouldn't be considered a tragedy if a character's fortune increased throughout the play, as this would be a good thing. Aristotle also says a good tragedy should portray a character who is somewhere in the middle between being inherently good and inherently bad. He says "There remains, then, the character between these two extremes - that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgement or frailty." Essentially, Aristotle is saying that the main character shouldn't be too good, as this wouldn't invoke any pity, however, the character also shouldn't be too evil, or else the audience wouldn't feel sorry for him and his bad misfortune. Lastly, Aristotle says a good tragedy should exhibit a character experiencing misfortune due to a flaw in his character, not necessarily because of bad or immoral behaviror. He says "It should come about as the result not of vice, but of some great error or frailty, in a character either such as we have described, or better rather than worse." Overall, Aristotle argues that a good tragedy should portray a character who is neither good nor bad, but rather somewhere in the middle, who experiences a change of fortune from good to bad due to some inherent flaw of his character.
column4: Sure, here is a rewritten version of the passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  One element of a tragic play, as outlined by Aristotle, is that there should be a significant shift in circumstances for the main character, from positive to negative. Aristotle emphasizes that a tragedy should showcase misfortune resulting from an error of judgment, rather than from moral deficiency. He suggests that the character should be in a state between virtue and villainy, experiencing a change of fortune that elevates his or her suffering to a tragic peak. Aristotle argues that the tragic narrative should depict a character experiencing misfortune due to a flaw in their character and not due to their character‚Äôs moral behavior. Overall, a tragedy should convey the experience of a character navigating misfortune due to an inherent issue.

column3: The Third Wave was an anti-democracy movement concocted by Ron Jones, a history teacher at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, CA. He started this experiment in 1967, in an attempt to teach his students how groups of people throughout history have had the advantage of influencing others to follow their path, regardless of how nefarious their actions were. He wanted to show the students first hand how this movement worked. He announced that he was starting a movement to eliminate democracy, and he started to get his students involved immediately. Jones instilled extensive rules and proper disciplinary skills into his students by the end of the first day. The movement picked up steam, and by the third day, the movement expended to over 40 students. They even had a salute resembling that of the Nazi regime. Everyone obeyed Jones. However, by the fourth day, more than 200 students joined in on the bandwagon, and the experiment was getting out of control. Therefore, Jones decided to end it by tricking his students into thinking that the Third Wave was a nationwide movement and that a Presidential Candidate would officially confirm its existence. in the end, that definitely did not happen. Instead, Jones simply announced that the students were a part of an experiment and that he was trying to show them how a group of people can band together to brainwash others and create a sense of superiority.
column4: Sure, here is the paraphrased passage.  "The Third Wave was a student-led movement led by Ron Jones in 1967. Jones' experiment aimed to teach his students about the dynamics of influencing others through various historical groups. He focused on showcasing this process through hands-on involvement. While Jones initially garnered a small group, it picked up momentum quickly. The movement reached a peak of 40 students by the third day, demonstrating the potency of this collective effort. However, Jones' plan to manipulate the students into thinking it was a national movement and an official Presidential endorsement backfired. Instead, Jones revealed that the students were part of an experiment, highlighting the potential for manipulation and control exercised by individuals to shape opinions."

column3: At the top of the structure of the ancient Egyptian system of goverment are the Gods. According to paragraph 1, "Egyptians believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy." Next were the pharaohs were believed as the gods in human form. "The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods." Below the pharaoh were nobles and priests.Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."  Finally, at the very bottom of the structure were farmers and slaves. "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles.
column4: The ancient Egyptian system of government was highly structured, with the gods holding supreme authority. This belief stemmed from the Egyptians' deep reverence for the gods and the recognition of their role in shaping the universe. The pharaohs were considered the epitome of the gods, embodying their divine characteristics through their rule and authority in society. Next to the pharaoh were the nobles and priests, who held a position of influence due to their ability to garner wealth through tribute payments. Priests were tasked with ensuring the gods' favor by performing rituals and overseeing sacred rituals. The farmers and slaves formed the lowest rung of the system, subject to the control of the pharaoh or their officials.

column4: The social hierarchy was categorized into distinct classes. The upper class consisted of gods and kings, with scribes and warriors occupying positions of authority. The middle class comprised merchants, manufacturers, and farmers, while the lower class consisted of slaves, the most marginalized group. The lowest class was occupied by the enslaved, whose importance was ranked lower than that of the upper class. This rigid system restricted opportunities for advancement, and due to the low rank of the lower classes, their involvement in government positions was minimal.

column3: In the article, "Egyptian Social Structures" by USHistory.org we learn how their society was structured like a pyramid. While gods are at the top, it is the pharaos , "Who were gods in human form" (2) who controlled the land.  Next in the pyramid are the nobles and priests who control the government and are "responsible for pleasing the gods" (6).  The Middle Class, (soldiers, merchants, and artisans) The middle class were those who made and sold goods or protected the land.  The largest population is made up of farmers and slaves who "toiled at the discretion of Pharaos and Nobles" (11) doing almost all physical labor.
column4: In the article, "Egyptian Social Structures," we learned that the ancient society functioned like a pyramid, with different levels of power and responsibility. At the apex of the pyramid were the gods, represented by the pharaohs, who held the reins of the land and controlled its affairs. Next came the nobles and priests, who held positions of power within the government and were responsible to pleasing the gods. The middle class, composed of soldiers, merchants, and artisans, played a crucial role in supplying the goods and
